New Records: England's Alex Hales and Jos Buttler produced the largest opening partnership in England's Twenty20 history, scoring 170 runs without losing a wicket.
Key Match Events: Alex Hales scored 86 off 47 balls, and Jos Buttler scored 80 off 49 balls, with Buttler adding 35 off his last 15 deliveries, including the six that ended the match.
Hardik Pandya scored 63 off 33 balls, but his innings inspired hope in England rather than striking fear.
England completed an all-run four after Mohammed Shami missed the ball and Suryakumar Yadav failed to catch Buttler, shoveling the ball further to the rope.
Pre-Game Insights: England captain Jos Buttler had promised to show no fear of Bhuvneshwar Kumar, against whom he had a notably poor record.
Post-Match Reflections: England captain Jos Buttler said that Hardik Pandya's innings had just'shown what a good wicket it was'.
England's Jos Buttler and Alex Hales walked from the field after their semi-final win against India.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The ground that witnessed England's worst moment in white-ball cricket, against Bangladesh in 2015, thus witnessed what stands perhaps just the 2019 World Cup final away from their finest.
Adil Rashid was outstanding, going at five an over and taking the key wicket of Yadav, and Chris Jordan replaced the injured Mark Wood and took three wickets in his first game of the tournament.
Others: England reached 170 with all 10 wickets and four overs to spare, and Pakistan await in Melbourne on Sunday.
